title: Fuel Volume Regulator Control Circuit/Open
description: Indicates a problem in the fuel volume regulator (FVR) control circuit, leading to an interruption of the signal.
symptoms: Check engine light, weak acceleration, difficulty starting.
causes: Sensor damage, wire break, PCM malfunction.
solutions: Repair or replace connections, replace sensor, reprogram PCM if necessary.
severity: Moderate - May affect
diagnosis: Check wires and connections, test sensor resistance, check PCM.

title: Fuel Volume Regulator Control Circuit Range/Performance
description: Indicates abnormal performance in the fuel volume control circuit within the range.
symptoms: Unstable engine speed, reduced efficiency.
causes: FVR sensor corrosion, unstable fuel pressure, electrical issues.
solutions: Replace sensor or adjust connections.
severity: Low to moderate - but
diagnosis: Check voltage, test sensor behavior under load.

title: Malfunction in Fuel Volume Regulator Control Circuit - Low Voltage
description: Low voltage in the fuel volume regulator control circuit below the expected range.
symptoms:
• Engine stall
• Difficulty starting
• Check engine light (MIL)
causes:
• Short to ground in wires
• Low reference feed voltage
• PCM control unit failure
solutions:
• Repair short in wires
• Check and replace fuel volume regulator
• Verify PCM voltage
severity: Moderate
diagnosis: Use an OBD device to measure circuit voltage and compare it with reference values.

title: Malfunction in Fuel Volume Regulator Control Circuit - High Voltage
description: High voltage in the fuel volume regulator control circuit above the allowed range.
symptoms:
• Rich engine running
• Black smoke from exhaust
• MIL illumination
causes:
• Short to supply voltage in wires
• Incorrect output from PCM control unit
• Contamination or damage to connectors
solutions:
• Repair short circuit in wires
• Clean or replace connectors
• Reprogram or replace PCM
severity: Moderate
diagnosis: Check signals using an oscilloscope to ensure voltage stability.

title: Malfunction in Fuel Cutoff Valve Circuit - Open Circuit
description: This message indicates an interruption in the electrical circuit of the fuel cutoff valve.
symptoms:
• Engine cannot start
• Check engine light illumination
• Loss of pressure in the fuel system
causes:
• Open or loose cable
• Internal fault in the valve
• Damage to the valve connector
solutions:
• Check and secure wires
• Replace the valve if necessary
• Inspect and maintain connectors
severity: High
diagnosis: Use an OBD scanner to activate the valve and monitor its response.

title: Malfunction in Fuel Cutoff Valve Circuit - Low Voltage
description: Low voltage in the fuel cutoff valve circuit below the required level.
symptoms:
• Engine misfires
• Vibration at idle
• MIL illumination
causes:
• Poor grounding
• Low control voltage from PCM
• Wire damage
solutions:
• Improve grounding
• Check PCM output
• Repair or replace damaged wires
severity: Moderate
diagnosis: Monitor circuit voltage while operating the valve using a multimeter.

title: Malfunction in Fuel Cutoff Valve Circuit - High Voltage
description: High voltage in the fuel cutoff valve circuit above the upper limit.
symptoms:
• Difficulty starting
• MIL illumination
• Unexpected valve response
causes:
• Short to supply voltage
• Fault in PCM control unit
• Contaminated connectors
solutions:
• Repair wire short circuit
• Clean connectors and apply dielectric grease
• Reprogram or replace PCM
severity: High
diagnosis: Check for unintended power connection to the valve.

title: Malfunction in Fuel Cutoff Valve “A” Circuit - Low Voltage
description: Low voltage in the main circuit of fuel cutoff valve “A”.
symptoms:
• Cranking without ignition
• MIL illumination
• Excessive fuel injection
causes:
• Damage to the wire harness
• Internal fault in the valve or PCM
• High resistance in the cable
solutions:
• Repair wire harness
• Replace the valve
• Check PCM output
severity: High
diagnosis: Use an OBD scanner to measure circuit voltage and compare it with specifications.

title: Malfunction in Fuel Cutoff Valve “A” Circuit - High Voltage
description: High voltage in the main circuit of fuel cutoff valve “A”.
symptoms:
• Engine flooding upon starting
• MIL illumination
• Strong fuel odor
causes:
• Short in wires to supply voltage
• Malfunctioning PCM output
• Accumulation of dirt on connectors
solutions:
• Repair wire short circuit
• Clean connectors
• Replace PCM when needed
severity: High
diagnosis: Inspect connections and ensure circuit is free of excess voltage during idle.

title: Camshaft Position Actuator Circuit (Bank 1)
description: Malfunction in the electrical circuit of the camshaft actuator for Bank 1.
symptoms: Engine vibration, delayed start, increased fuel consumption.
causes: Faulty solenoid, disconnected or damaged wire, unstable PCM.
solutions: Replace solenoid, repair connections, update PCM.
severity: High - Must be addressed
diagnosis: Check actuator voltage, read timing using OBD2.

title: Camshaft Timing Over-Advanced (Bank 1)
description: Camshaft timing for Bank 1 is more advanced than necessary.
symptoms: Poor performance, engine knocking sound, CEL.
causes: Dirty or low oil, faulty VVT valve.
solutions: Change oil, replace VVT, clean internal filter.
severity: High - May cause damage
diagnosis: Check oil pressure, read camshaft timing.

severity: Moderate

title: Turbo Pressure Control Circuit  A Range/Performance
description: This diagnostic trouble code (DTC) signifies that the powertrain control module (PCM) has detected that the actual boost pressure from the turbocharger or supercharger is not within the desired range commanded by the PCM for the wastegate control solenoid  A.
symptoms:
• Reduced engine power and acceleration
• Turbocharger or supercharger underboost or overboost
• Check Engine Light (MIL) illumination
• Potential for abnormal engine noise
causes:
• Faulty turbocharger boost control solenoid  A
• Vacuum leaks in the boost control system
• Blocked or restricted wastegate actuator
• Issues with the MAP (Manifold Absolute Pressure) or BARO (Barometric Pressure) sensor
• Problems with the wiring or connections to the boost control solenoid or sensors
• PCM malfunction
solutions:
• Inspect all vacuum hoses and connections for leaks, repairing or replacing as necessary.
• Test the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A for proper operation and replace if faulty.
• Check the wastegate actuator for free movement; ensure it's not stuck or binding.
• Verify the functionality of the MAP and BARO sensors; replace if readings are inaccurate.
• Examine the wiring and connectors to the boost control solenoid and related sensors for damage or corrosion; repair as needed.
• In some cases, reprogramming or replacing the PCM may be necessary.
severity: Moderate to High - Can lead to engine damage if overboost occurs.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to retrieve the P0046 code and other related codes. Monitor live data from the MAP sensor, BARO sensor, and boost control solenoid duty cycle. Perform a visual inspection of all vacuum lines and electrical connections. Conduct actuator tests if the scan tool allows. A smoke test can help identify vacuum leaks. Manually check the wastegate for proper movement.

title: Turbo Pressure Control Circuit  A Low
description: The diagnostic trouble code P0047 indicates that the powertrain control module (PCM) has detected a low voltage condition in the control circuit for the turbocharger/supercharger wastegate solenoid  A. This typically means the PCM is commanding the solenoid, but the actual voltage in the circuit is lower than expected.
symptoms:
• Noticeable decrease in engine power and acceleration.
• The turbocharger or supercharger may not be producing the expected level of boost.
• The Check Engine Light (MIL) will likely illuminate.
• In some cases, the engine might run rough or exhibit unusual behavior.
causes:
• Short to ground in the wiring or connectors associated with the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A.
• A faulty turbocharger boost control solenoid  A itself, possibly due to an internal short.
• Poor electrical connections (corrosion, loose pins) at the solenoid or the PCM.
• In rare cases, a malfunction within the PCM could be the cause.
solutions:
• Begin by performing a thorough visual inspection of all wiring and connectors related to the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A. Look for any signs of damage, chafing, or corrosion.
• Use a multimeter to check the voltage and ground signals at the solenoid connector as commanded by the PCM.
• Test the resistance of the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A itself. Compare the reading to the manufacturer's specifications. A very low resistance reading could indicate an internal short.
• Ensure all electrical connections are clean and secure.
• If a wiring issue is suspected, carefully check the continuity of the wires between the solenoid and the PCM.
• In some instances, replacing the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A will resolve the issue.
• As a last resort, consider the possibility of a PCM fault. However, this is less common, and other potential causes should be ruled out first.
severity: Moderate - Can affect vehicle performance and potentially lead to further issues if not addressed.
diagnosis: Utilize an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0047 code and check for any other related trouble codes. Monitor live data parameters related to boost pressure and the wastegate solenoid control. Perform an actuator test if your scan tool has this capability. A multimeter will be essential for diagnosing electrical issues such as shorts and open circuits. Refer to the vehicle's service manual for specific diagnostic procedures and wiring diagrams.

title: Turbo Pressure Control Circuit  A High
description: This diagnostic trouble code (DTC) P0048 indicates that the powertrain control module (PCM) has detected an abnormally high voltage in the control circuit for the turbocharger/supercharger wastegate solenoid  A. This means the voltage in the circuit is exceeding the expected or commanded level.
symptoms:
• Noticeable decrease in engine power and acceleration.
• The turbocharger or supercharger may be producing excessive boost (overboost condition).
• The Check Engine Light (MIL) will illuminate.
• Potential for engine knocking or other abnormal noises due to overboost.
• In some cases, the engine might enter a 'limp mode' to prevent damage.
causes:
• Short to a power source in the wiring or connectors associated with the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A.
• A faulty turbocharger boost control solenoid  A itself, possibly due to an internal issue causing excessive current draw or incorrect signaling.
• Poor electrical connections (corrosion, loose pins) at the solenoid or the PCM that might be causing a false high voltage reading.
• Less likely, a malfunction within the PCM could be sending an incorrect high voltage signal to the solenoid.
solutions:
• Begin with a careful visual inspection of all wiring and connectors related to the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A. Look for any signs of damage, melting, or chafing that could indicate a short to power.
• Use a multimeter to check the voltage at the solenoid connector. Compare the reading to the expected voltage as commanded by the PCM.
• Test the resistance of the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A. An unusually high resistance might indicate an internal fault.
• Ensure all electrical connections are clean and secure.
• If a wiring short to power is suspected, carefully trace the circuit to identify and repair the short.
• In some cases, replacing the turbocharger boost control solenoid  A will resolve the high voltage issue.
• Although less common, the PCM could be the source of the problem. However, other potential causes should be thoroughly investigated first.
severity: High - An overboost condition can lead to significant engine damage if not addressed promptly.
diagnosis: Employ an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0048 code and check for any other related DTCs. Monitor live data parameters, particularly the boost pressure and the duty cycle of the wastegate solenoid. Perform an actuator test if available on your scan tool. A multimeter is crucial for pinpointing electrical faults such as shorts to power. Refer to the vehicle's specific service manual for detailed diagnostic steps and wiring schematics.

title: Turbo/Super Charger Turbine Overspeed
description: This trouble code indicates that the engine's control system has detected that the rotational speed of the turbocharger or supercharger turbine has exceeded the manufacturer's specified maximum limit.
symptoms:
• Whining or high-pitched noise coming from the turbocharger or supercharger.
• Noticeable decrease in engine power and acceleration.
• The Check Engine Light (MIL) will illuminate.
• Potential for damage to the turbocharger or supercharger components.
causes:
• Faulty or misadjusted turbocharger wastegate or supercharger bypass valve, preventing proper pressure regulation.
• Leaks in the intake or exhaust system that could cause the turbo/supercharger to spin faster than intended.
• Malfunction of the boost pressure sensor, providing incorrect readings to the engine control unit (ECU) or powertrain control module (PCM).
• Issues with the engine control software or calibration.
• Mechanical failure within the turbocharger or supercharger unit itself.
solutions:
• Inspect the turbocharger wastegate or supercharger bypass valve for proper operation and adjustment. Ensure it is opening and closing correctly.
• Check for any leaks in the intake and exhaust systems, including hoses, clamps, and gaskets. Repair any leaks found.
• Test the boost pressure sensor for accuracy. Replace if it is providing faulty readings.
• Consult the vehicle's service manual for any relevant technical service bulletins (TSBs) or software updates related to boost control.
• If mechanical failure of the turbocharger or supercharger is suspected, a thorough inspection and potential replacement of the unit may be necessary.
severity: High - Operating the vehicle with a turbo/supercharger overspeed condition can lead to significant and costly damage to the forced induction system.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0049 code and check for any other related trouble codes. Monitor live data parameters, including turbocharger/supercharger RPM (if available), boost pressure, and the status of the wastegate/bypass valve. Perform a visual and physical inspection of the turbo/supercharger unit and associated components. A boost leak test can help identify leaks in the system. Refer to the vehicle's service manual for specific diagnostic procedures and specifications.

title: HO2S Heater Circuit (Bank 2 Sensor 1)
description: This diagnostic trouble code (DTC) P0050 indicates a problem with the heater circuit of the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor (HO2S). Bank 2 refers to the side of the engine that does not contain cylinder #1, and Sensor 1 is the pre-catalytic converter oxygen sensor.
symptoms:
• The Check Engine Light (MIL) will illuminate.
• Increased fuel consumption.
• The engine may take longer to enter closed-loop operation.
• Potential for the engine to run rich or lean.
causes:
• Faulty Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor heater element.
• Open or short circuit in the heater circuit wiring.
• Poor electrical connections at the sensor or the engine control module (ECM)/powertrain control module (PCM).
• Blown fuse in the heater circuit (if applicable).
• Malfunction of the ECM/PCM.
solutions:
• Inspect the wiring and connectors to the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor for any signs of damage, corrosion, or loose connections.
• Check the resistance of the oxygen sensor heater element using a multimeter. Compare the reading to the manufacturer's specifications.
• Verify the presence of voltage and ground at the sensor's heater circuit connector when the engine is running (as commanded by the ECM/PCM).
• Check the relevant fuses in the vehicle's electrical system.
• If the sensor heater element is faulty or the wiring is damaged, replace the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor.
• In rare cases, a malfunction in the ECM/PCM may be the cause, requiring diagnosis and potential replacement by a qualified technician.
severity: Moderate - Can impact fuel efficiency and emissions.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0050 code and check for any other related DTCs. Monitor the live data from the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor, paying attention to its response and heater status. A multimeter will be necessary to test the continuity and voltage in the heater circuit. Refer to the vehicle's service manual for specific wiring diagrams and diagnostic procedures.

title: HO2S Heater Circuit Low (Bank 2 Sensor 1)
description: This diagnostic trouble code (DTC) P0051 indicates that the powertrain control module (PCM) has detected a low voltage condition in the heater circuit of the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor (HO2S). This means the voltage supplied to the heater element is below the expected level.
symptoms:
• The Check Engine Light (MIL) will illuminate.
• The oxygen sensor may take longer to reach its operating temperature.
• Increased fuel consumption.
• Potential for the engine to run rich or lean due to delayed sensor activation.
causes:
• Short to ground in the heater circuit wiring for Bank 2, Sensor 1.
• High resistance in the heater circuit due to corrosion or loose connections.
• Faulty Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor heater element with increased internal resistance.
• Weak or insufficient power supply to the heater circuit.
• Malfunction of the ECM/PCM that controls the heater circuit.
solutions:
• Perform a thorough visual inspection of the wiring and connectors associated with the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor. Look for any signs of damage, chafing, or corrosion.
• Use a multimeter to check the voltage at the heater circuit connector of the sensor. Compare the reading to the expected voltage.
• Test the resistance of the oxygen sensor heater element. A high resistance reading indicates a potential fault within the sensor.
• Ensure all electrical connections are clean and secure.
• Check the continuity of the heater circuit wiring to identify any open circuits or high resistance areas.
• In many cases, replacing the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor will resolve the issue.
• Investigate the power supply to the heater circuit to ensure it is within the specified range.
• As a last resort, consider the possibility of an ECM/PCM malfunction, requiring further diagnosis and potential replacement by a qualified technician.
severity: Moderate - Can affect fuel efficiency and emissions, and may indicate a failing sensor.
diagnosis: Utilize an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0051 code and check for any other related DTCs. Monitor the live data from the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor, paying attention to its heater status and response time. A multimeter is essential for diagnosing electrical issues such as shorts, open circuits, and resistance problems. Refer to the vehicle's service manual for specific wiring diagrams and diagnostic procedures.

title: HO2S Heater Circuit High (Bank 2 Sensor 1)
description: This diagnostic trouble code (DTC) P0052 indicates that the powertrain control module (PCM) has detected a high voltage condition in the heater circuit of the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor (HO2S). This means the voltage supplied to the heater element is above the expected level.
symptoms:
• The Check Engine Light (MIL) will illuminate.
• The oxygen sensor may overheat.
• Potential for damage to the oxygen sensor or the PCM.
• Possible lean engine condition due to inaccurate sensor readings.
causes:
• Short to a power source in the heater circuit wiring for Bank 2, Sensor 1.
• Faulty Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor with an internal short causing excessive current draw.
• Poor grounding of the heater circuit, leading to a higher voltage reading.
• Malfunction of the ECM/PCM that controls the heater circuit, causing it to output excessive voltage.
solutions:
• Perform a thorough visual inspection of the wiring and connectors associated with the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor. Look for any signs of damage, melting, or chafing that could indicate a short to power.
• Use a multimeter to check the voltage at the heater circuit connector of the sensor. Compare the reading to the expected voltage.
• Test the resistance of the oxygen sensor heater element. A very low resistance reading could indicate an internal short within the sensor.
• Ensure the heater circuit has a proper ground connection.
• Check the continuity of the heater circuit wiring to identify any shorts to a power source.
• In many cases, replacing the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor will resolve the issue, especially if an internal short is suspected.
• Investigate the output of the ECM/PCM for the heater circuit. If the PCM is outputting excessive voltage, it may need to be repaired or replaced by a qualified technician.
severity: Moderate to High - Can damage the oxygen sensor or the PCM and affect engine performance.
diagnosis: Utilize an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0052 code and check for any other related DTCs. Monitor the live data from the Bank 2, Sensor 1 oxygen sensor, paying attention to its heater status and response time. A multimeter is crucial for diagnosing electrical issues such as shorts to power, ground problems, and resistance values. Refer to the vehicle's service manual for specific wiring diagrams and diagnostic procedures.

title: Injector Circuit Malfunction
description: Indicates a general malfunction in the injector circuit. This could affect one or more injectors.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, poor performance, misfires, rough idle, potential stalling.
causes: Faulty injector(s), wiring issues, poor connections, PCM problem.
solutions: Inspect and test injectors, repair wiring, ensure good connections, diagnose PCM.
severity: Moderate to High
diagnosis: Check injector control circuit voltage and operation.

title: Injector Circuit Malfunction - Cylinder 1
description: This code indicates a specific problem with the electrical circuit controlling the fuel injector for cylinder number 1. The PCM has detected an issue such as an open or short circuit in this specific injector's control.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, misfire in cylinder 1, noticeable rough idle, loss of power, potential engine vibration.
causes: Faulty fuel injector for cylinder 1, wiring problems specific to the cylinder 1 injector circuit (open, short, high resistance), poor electrical connection at the cylinder 1 injector, faulty PCM injector driver for cylinder 1.
solutions: Inspect the wiring and connector specifically for the cylinder 1 fuel injector for any damage or corrosion, test the resistance of the cylinder 1 fuel injector, check for proper voltage supply and ground at the injector connector, verify the PCM's ability to send a control signal to the cylinder 1 injector.
severity: Moderate - Will cause a noticeable engine misfire and affect performance.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0201 code. Perform a visual inspection of the wiring and connector for the cylinder 1 injector. Use a multimeter to check the resistance of the injector and the voltage/ground at the connector. Perform an injector pulse test for cylinder 1.

title: Cold Start Injector 1 Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the cold start injector 1 circuit. This injector is typically used to provide extra fuel during cold engine starts.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, difficulty starting in cold weather, rough idle during cold start, potential stalling.
causes: Faulty cold start injector 1, wiring issues to the cold start injector, poor connections, faulty cold start timing switch or sensor, PCM problem.
solutions: Inspect the wiring and connector for the cold start injector, test the resistance and operation of the cold start injector, check the cold start timing switch and its circuit, verify the PCM's control of the cold start injector.
severity: Low to Moderate - Primarily affects cold starting.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0213 code. Perform a visual inspection of the wiring and connector for the cold start injector. Use a multimeter to check the resistance and voltage at the injector. Check the cold start system components.

title: Cold Start Injector 2 Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the cold start injector 2 circuit. This injector is typically used to provide extra fuel during cold engine starts.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, difficulty starting in cold weather, rough idle during cold start, potential stalling.
causes: Faulty cold start injector 2, wiring issues to the cold start injector, poor connections, faulty cold start timing switch or sensor, PCM problem.
solutions: Inspect the wiring and connector for the cold start injector, test the resistance and operation of the cold start injector, check the cold start timing switch and its circuit, verify the PCM's control of the cold start injector.
severity: Low to Moderate - Primarily affects cold starting.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0214 code. Perform a visual inspection of the wiring and connector for the cold start injector. Use a multimeter to check the resistance and voltage at the injector. Check the cold start system components.

title: Engine Shutoff Solenoid Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the engine shutoff solenoid circuit. This solenoid is responsible for cutting off fuel supply to stop the engine.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, engine may not start, engine may not shut off properly, potential stalling.
causes: Faulty engine shutoff solenoid, wiring issues to the solenoid, poor connections, faulty ignition switch, PCM problem.
solutions: Inspect the wiring and connector for the shutoff solenoid, test the resistance and operation of the solenoid, check the ignition switch circuit, verify the PCM's control of the solenoid.
severity: High - Can prevent the engine from starting or stopping.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0215 code. Perform a visual inspection of the wiring and connector for the shutoff solenoid. Use a multimeter to check the resistance and voltage at the solenoid. Check the ignition switch and PCM control signals.

title: Injection Timing Control Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the injection timing control circuit. This is crucial for proper engine operation, especially in diesel engines.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, poor performance, reduced fuel economy, hard starting, excessive smoke, potential knocking or pinging.
causes: Faulty injection timing control solenoid or actuator, wiring issues to the control mechanism, poor connections, faulty timing sensor, PCM problem.
solutions: Inspect the wiring and connectors for the injection timing control components, test the operation of the timing control solenoid or actuator, check the timing sensor and its circuit, verify the PCM's control of the injection timing.
severity: High - Can significantly impact engine performance and potentially cause damage.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0216 code. Monitor injection timing parameters with a scan tool. Perform a visual inspection of the wiring and control components. Use a multimeter to check circuits. Consult the vehicle's service manual for specific tests.

title: Engine Over Temperature Condition
description: This code indicates that the engine coolant temperature has exceeded a critical threshold.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, temperature gauge reading very high, engine overheating, potential steam from the engine bay, loss of power.
causes: Low coolant level, faulty thermostat, radiator issues (blockage, leaks), faulty water pump, faulty cooling fan(s), air trapped in the cooling system, faulty ECT sensor reporting incorrectly.
solutions: Check and replenish coolant level, test and replace thermostat if faulty, inspect radiator for leaks or blockages, check water pump operation, verify cooling fan operation, bleed air from the cooling system, test and replace ECT sensor if faulty.
severity: High - Can lead to severe engine damage if not addressed immediately.
diagnosis: Check the temperature gauge and any other temperature indicators. Verify coolant level. Inspect the radiator, hoses, and water pump for leaks or damage. Check thermostat operation. Ensure cooling fans are working correctly. Use a scan tool to read the actual ECT sensor value.

title: Transmission Fluid Over Temperature Condition
description: This code indicates that the transmission fluid temperature has exceeded a critical threshold.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, transmission slipping, rough or delayed shifting, potential loss of gear engagement, transmission warning light may also be illuminated.
causes: Heavy towing or hauling, aggressive driving, low transmission fluid level, faulty transmission fluid temperature sensor, blocked transmission cooler, internal transmission problems.
solutions: Check and replenish transmission fluid level, inspect transmission cooler for blockages, reduce driving intensity or load, test and replace transmission fluid temperature sensor if faulty, address any internal transmission issues.
severity: High - Can lead to severe transmission damage if not addressed.
diagnosis: Check the transmission fluid level and condition. Inspect the transmission cooler and lines for leaks or blockages. Use a scan tool to monitor the transmission fluid temperature sensor reading. Consider a transmission fluid flush and filter change if the fluid is old or contaminated.

title: Engine Overspeed Condition
description: This code indicates that the engine RPM (revolutions per minute) has exceeded the manufacturer's specified limit.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, engine running at excessively high RPM, potential loud engine noise, possible damage to engine components.
causes: Aggressive acceleration, downshifting at high speeds, malfunction of the throttle control system, PCM malfunction.
solutions: Avoid excessive acceleration and high-speed downshifting, inspect the throttle control system for proper operation, verify PCM functionality.
severity: High - Can cause significant engine damage.
diagnosis: Check the engine RPM with a scan tool. Inspect the throttle body and its control mechanisms. Verify the proper operation of the accelerator pedal position sensor. Check for any PCM-related issues.

title: Throttle/Pedal Position Sensor/Switch B Circuit Malfunction

title: Cylinder 1 Injector Circuit Low

title: Vehicle Overspeed Condition
description: This code indicates that the vehicle speed has exceeded the manufacturer's specified limit. This is often a stored, non-critical code.
symptoms: Check Engine Light (may or may not illuminate), no noticeable drivability issues in many cases.
causes: Exceeding the vehicle's programmed speed limiter.
solutions: Adhere to posted speed limits and the vehicle's speed limitations. The code may clear itself after a period of normal driving.
severity: Low - Primarily an informational code.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0297 code. Check the vehicle's speed limiter settings if accessible.

title: Engine Oil Temperature Too High
description: This code indicates that the engine oil temperature has exceeded a critical threshold.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, high oil temperature warning light may illuminate, potential engine knocking or pinging, reduced engine performance.
causes: Low engine oil level, heavy engine load, hot ambient temperatures, faulty engine oil temperature sensor, blocked oil cooler (if equipped), internal engine problems.
solutions: Check and replenish engine oil level, reduce engine load, ensure proper cooling system operation, test and replace engine oil temperature sensor, inspect oil cooler for blockages, address any internal engine issues.
severity: High - Can lead to significant engine damage.
diagnosis: Check the oil temperature gauge or display. Use a scan tool to read the engine oil temperature sensor value. Verify engine oil level and condition. Inspect the oil cooler and its lines.

title: Turbocharger/Supercharger Underboost Condition
description: This code indicates that the actual boost pressure produced by the turbocharger or supercharger is lower than the manufacturer's specified limit.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, noticeable lack of power and acceleration, poor engine performance, potential for increased exhaust emissions.
causes: Vacuum leaks in the boost control system, faulty wastegate control solenoid, stuck or binding wastegate, faulty boost pressure sensor, intake or exhaust restrictions, turbocharger/supercharger issues.
solutions: Inspect all vacuum hoses and connections for leaks, test and replace wastegate control solenoid, check wastegate for proper movement, test and replace boost pressure sensor, check for intake and exhaust restrictions, inspect turbocharger/supercharger for damage.
severity: Moderate - Affects engine performance and fuel efficiency.
diagnosis: Use a scan tool to monitor boost pressure readings. Check the vacuum lines and connections related to the turbocharger/supercharger. Test the wastegate control solenoid and the boost pressure sensor. Inspect for any blockages in the intake or exhaust system.

title: Random/Multiple Cylinder Misfire Detected
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected random misfires occurring in two or more cylinders or that the specific misfiring cylinder cannot be identified.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, rough idle, lack of power, engine hesitation, potential stalling, increased emissions, poor fuel economy.
causes: Ignition system problems (faulty spark plugs, ignition wires, ignition coils), fuel system problems (low fuel pressure, faulty fuel pump, clogged fuel filter, faulty fuel injectors), vacuum leaks, low compression, faulty camshaft or crankshaft position sensor, PCM problem.
solutions: Inspect and replace faulty spark plugs, ignition wires, and ignition coils. Check fuel pressure and test fuel injectors. Check for vacuum leaks. Perform a compression test. Check camshaft and crankshaft position sensors. Diagnose PCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Can cause engine damage if not addressed.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0300 code and check for any other misfire codes (P0301-P0312). Monitor live engine data, including RPM, engine load, and misfire counts per cylinder. Perform a visual inspection of ignition and fuel system components.

title: Cylinder 1 Misfire Detected
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected a misfire occurring in cylinder number 1.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, rough idle, lack of power, engine hesitation, potential engine vibration.
causes: Faulty spark plug in cylinder 1, faulty ignition wire to cylinder 1, faulty ignition coil for cylinder 1, faulty fuel injector for cylinder 1, low compression in cylinder 1, vacuum leak affecting cylinder 1, valve problems in cylinder 1.
solutions: Inspect and replace the spark plug in cylinder 1, check and replace the ignition wire to cylinder 1, test and replace the ignition coil for cylinder 1, test and replace the fuel injector for cylinder 1, perform a compression test on cylinder 1, check for vacuum leaks.
severity: Moderate - Can affect engine performance and potentially cause damage.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0301 code. Monitor live engine data for misfires in cylinder 1. Perform a visual inspection of the ignition and fuel system components for cylinder 1. Consider swapping components with another cylinder to see if the misfire follows.

title: Cylinder 2 Misfire Detected
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected a misfire occurring in cylinder number 2.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, rough idle, lack of power, engine hesitation, potential engine vibration.
causes: Faulty spark plug in cylinder 2, faulty ignition wire to cylinder 2, faulty ignition coil for cylinder 2, faulty fuel injector for cylinder 2, low compression in cylinder 2, vacuum leak affecting cylinder 2, valve problems in cylinder 2.
solutions: Inspect and replace the spark plug in cylinder 2, check and replace the ignition wire to cylinder 2, test and replace the ignition coil for cylinder 2, test and replace the fuel injector for cylinder 2, perform a compression test on cylinder 2, check for vacuum leaks.
severity: Moderate - Can affect engine performance and potentially cause damage.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0302 code. Monitor live engine data for misfires in cylinder 2. Perform a visual inspection of the ignition and fuel system components for cylinder 2. Consider swapping components with another cylinder to see if the misfire follows.

title: Misfire Detected With Low Fuel
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected engine misfires occurring when the fuel level in the tank is low.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, engine misfires primarily when the fuel tank is low, rough idle, potential stalling.
causes: Low fuel level causing the fuel pump to suck air, faulty fuel pump pickup, clogged fuel filter exacerbating low fuel conditions.
solutions: Keep the fuel level above a quarter tank, inspect and test the fuel pump and its pickup, replace the fuel filter.
severity: Low to Moderate - Primarily occurs under specific conditions.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0313 code. Note the fuel level at the time of the misfire. Check fuel pressure. Inspect the fuel pump and filter.

title: Single Cylinder Misfire - Cylinder Number Not Specified
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected a misfire in a single cylinder, but the specific cylinder number cannot be identified.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, rough idle, lack of power, engine hesitation, potential engine vibration.
causes: Ignition system problems (faulty spark plug, ignition wire, ignition coil), fuel system problems (faulty fuel injector), low compression, vacuum leak.
solutions: Inspect spark plugs, ignition wires, and ignition coils. Test fuel injectors. Check for vacuum leaks. Perform a compression test.
severity: Moderate - Can affect engine performance and potentially cause damage.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0314 code. Monitor live engine data for misfires. Perform a visual inspection of the ignition and fuel system components.

title: Crankshaft Position System Variation Not Learned
description: This code indicates that the PCM has not learned the variations in the crankshaft position sensor signal, which is necessary for accurate misfire detection.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, potential for inaccurate misfire detection, no noticeable drivability issues in many cases.
causes: PCM replacement or reprogramming without performing a crankshaft position variation learn procedure.
solutions: Perform a crankshaft position variation learn procedure using a compatible scan tool.
severity: Low - Primarily affects diagnostic capabilities.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0315 code. Check if the PCM has been recently replaced or reprogrammed. Perform the learn procedure.

title: Misfire Detected on Startup (First 1000 Revolutions)
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected engine misfires occurring during the initial startup phase (within the first 1000 engine revolutions).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, hard starting, rough idle immediately after starting, potential stalling after starting.
causes: Faulty spark plugs, faulty ignition wires, faulty ignition coils, faulty fuel injectors, low compression, vacuum leaks, issues with cold start enrichment.
solutions: Inspect and replace faulty spark plugs, ignition wires, and ignition coils. Test and replace faulty fuel injectors. Check compression. Look for vacuum leaks. Investigate cold start system.
severity: Moderate - Affects engine starting and initial operation.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0316 code. Monitor live engine data during startup. Perform a visual inspection of ignition and fuel system components.

title: Rough Road Sensor  A Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the rough road sensor  A. This sensor helps the PCM distinguish between genuine misfires and vibrations caused by rough road conditions.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, potential for inaccurate misfire detection, no noticeable drivability issues in many cases.
causes: Faulty rough road sensor  A, wiring issues to the sensor, poor connections, PCM problem.
solutions: Replace rough road sensor  A, repair wiring, ensure good connections, diagnose PCM.
severity: Low - Primarily affects diagnostic capabilities.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0317 code. Check the rough road sensor  A reading and circuit. Inspect wiring and connections.

title: Rough Road Sensor  A Signal Circuit Range/Performance
description: This code indicates that the signal from the rough road sensor  A is outside the expected range or not performing correctly.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, potential for inaccurate misfire detection.
causes: Faulty rough road sensor  A, loose mounting, PCM problem.
solutions: Replace rough road sensor  A, ensure proper mounting, diagnose PCM.
severity: Low - Primarily affects diagnostic capabilities.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the P0318 code. Monitor the rough road sensor  A signal. Check the sensor's mounting.

title: Rough Road Sensor B Circuit Malfunction

title: Ignition/Distributor Engine Speed Input Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the circuit that provides engine speed information to the PCM, often from the ignition system or distributor.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, engine may not start, intermittent stalling, erratic RPM readings on the tachometer.
causes: Faulty crankshaft position sensor, faulty camshaft position sensor, wiring issues between the sensor and PCM, faulty ignition module or distributor, PCM problem.
solutions: Replace faulty crankshaft or camshaft position sensor, repair wiring, replace faulty ignition module or distributor, diagnose PCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Can affect engine starting and running.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to check RPM readings and the signals from the crankshaft and camshaft position sensors. Inspect wiring and connections.

title: Ignition/Distributor Engine Speed Input Circuit Range/Performance
description: This code indicates that the signal from the engine speed input circuit is outside the expected range or not performing correctly.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, unstable RPM readings, intermittent engine problems.
causes: Faulty crankshaft position sensor, faulty camshaft position sensor, loose or damaged wiring, PCM problem.
solutions: Replace faulty crankshaft or camshaft position sensor, repair or secure wiring, diagnose PCM.
severity: Moderate
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to monitor RPM signals and compare them to expected values. Check wiring and sensor connections.

solutions: Replace faulty crankshaft position sensor, repair or reconnect wiring, replace faulty ignition module or distributor, diagnose PCM.
severity: High - Prevents the engine from starting.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to check for an RPM signal during cranking. Inspect wiring and sensor connections. Check power and ground to the sensors and ignition components.

solutions: Check and secure all wiring connections, replace faulty crankshaft or camshaft position sensor, diagnose PCM.
severity: Moderate - Can cause unpredictable engine behavior.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to monitor the RPM signal for dropouts or inconsistencies. Check wiring and connections for looseness or corrosion.

title: Knock Control System Malfunction

title: Catalyst System Efficiency Below Threshold (Bank 1)
description: This code indicates that the catalytic converter on bank 1 is not operating at the required efficiency level.

solutions: Replace faulty catalytic converter, replace faulty oxygen sensors, repair exhaust leaks, address engine misfires, correct fuel mixture issues.
severity: Moderate - Affects emissions and can lead to failed inspections.
diagnosis: Use an OBD-II scanner to monitor the upstream and downstream oxygen sensor readings for bank 1. Check for exhaust leaks. Address any misfire or fuel trim issues.

title: Evaporative Emission Control System Malfunction
description: This code indicates a general problem with the Evaporative Emission Control (EVAP) system, which prevents fuel vapors from escaping into the atmosphere.

title: Evaporative Emission Control System Purge Control Valve Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the Evaporative Emission Control (EVAP) system purge control valve.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, potential for fuel odor, poor fuel economy.
causes: Faulty purge control valve, wiring issues to the valve, poor connections, faulty PCM.
solutions: Test and replace purge control valve, repair wiring, ensure good connections, diagnose PCM.
severity: Low to Moderate - Primarily affects emissions and fuel economy.
diagnosis: Check the voltage and control signal to the purge control valve. Inspect wiring and connections.

title: Evaporative Emission Control System Purge Control Valve Circuit Open
description: This code indicates an open circuit in the electrical circuit for the Evaporative Emission Control (EVAP) system purge control valve.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, potential for fuel odor, poor fuel economy.
causes: Open circuit in wiring to purge control valve, faulty valve, faulty PCM.
solutions: Repair open circuit in wiring, replace purge control valve, diagnose PCM.
severity: Low to Moderate - Primarily affects emissions and fuel economy.
diagnosis: Check for voltage at the purge control valve connector. Inspect wiring for breaks.

title: Evaporative Emission Control System Purge Control Valve Circuit Shorted
description: This code indicates a short circuit in the electrical circuit for the Evaporative Emission Control (EVAP) system purge control valve.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, potential for fuel odor, poor fuel economy.
causes: Short to power or ground in wiring to purge control valve, faulty valve, faulty PCM.
solutions: Repair short circuit in wiring, replace purge control valve, diagnose PCM.
severity: Low to Moderate - Primarily affects emissions and fuel economy.
diagnosis: Check for shorts to power or ground at the purge control valve connector. Inspect wiring.

title: Fuel Tank Pressure Sensor Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the fuel tank pressure (FTP) sensor, which monitors pressure in the fuel tank for the EVAP system.

causes: Faulty fuel tank pressure sensor, wiring issues to the sensor, poor connections, faulty PCM.
solutions: Test and replace fuel tank pressure sensor, repair wiring, ensure good connections, diagnose PCM.
severity: Low to Moderate - Primarily affects emissions.
diagnosis: Check the voltage and signal from the fuel tank pressure sensor. Inspect wiring and connections.

title: Fuel Tank Pressure Sensor Circuit Range/Performance
description: This code indicates that the signal from the fuel tank pressure (FTP) sensor is outside the expected range.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, potential for fuel odor, EVAP system malfunction.
causes: Faulty fuel tank pressure sensor, blockage in EVAP system, vacuum leaks, PCM problem.
solutions: Test and replace fuel tank pressure sensor, check for EVAP system blockages, repair vacuum leaks, diagnose PCM.
severity: Low to Moderate - Primarily affects emissions.
diagnosis: Monitor the fuel tank pressure sensor reading with a scan tool. Perform EVAP system tests.

title: Fuel Tank Pressure Sensor Circuit Low Input

title: Fuel Tank Pressure Sensor Circuit High Input

title: Evaporative Emission Control System Leak Detected (Large Leak)
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected a large leak in the Evaporative Emission Control (EVAP) system.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, noticeable fuel odor.
causes: Loose or missing fuel cap, large leaks in EVAP hoses or lines, faulty purge or vent valve stuck open.
solutions: Check and tighten or replace fuel cap, inspect and repair or replace EVAP hoses and lines, test and replace purge or vent valve.
severity: Moderate - Primarily affects emissions and can cause fuel odor.
diagnosis: Perform a visual inspection of the fuel cap and EVAP system hoses and lines. Perform an EVAP system leak test, often using a smoke machine.

title: Evaporative Emission Control System Leak Detected (Very Small Leak)
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected a very small leak in the Evaporative Emission Control (EVAP) system.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, may or may not have a noticeable fuel odor.
causes: Loose or faulty fuel cap, very small leaks in EVAP hoses or lines, slightly faulty purge or vent valve, faulty fuel tank pressure sensor.
solutions: Check and tighten or replace fuel cap, inspect and repair or replace EVAP hoses and lines, test and replace purge or vent valve, test and replace fuel tank pressure sensor.
severity: Low - Primarily affects emissions.
diagnosis: Perform a thorough EVAP system leak test, often requiring specialized equipment like a smoke machine with a sensitive pressure gauge. Check the fuel cap.

title: Evaporative Emission Control System Leak Detected (Fuel Cap Loose/Off)
description: This code specifically indicates that the PCM has detected a leak in the Evaporative Emission Control (EVAP) system likely due to a loose or missing fuel cap.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, possible fuel odor.
causes: Loose or missing fuel cap.
solutions: Check and tighten or replace the fuel cap. The code may clear itself after a period of normal driving.
severity: Low - Primarily affects emissions.
diagnosis: Visually inspect the fuel cap to ensure it is properly installed and in good condition. Use an OBD-II scanner to confirm the code.

title: Cooling Fan 1 Control Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the primary cooling fan.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, cooling fan not operating or constantly running, potential for engine overheating.
causes: Faulty cooling fan motor, faulty cooling fan relay, wiring issues to the fan or relay, faulty coolant temperature sensor, faulty PCM.
solutions: Test and replace cooling fan motor, test and replace cooling fan relay, repair wiring, test and replace coolant temperature sensor, diagnose PCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Can lead to engine overheating.
diagnosis: Check for power and ground at the cooling fan motor. Test the cooling fan relay and its control circuit. Inspect wiring for damage or corrosion. Monitor coolant temperature sensor readings.

title: Cooling Fan 2 Control Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the secondary cooling fan (if equipped).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, secondary cooling fan not operating or constantly running, potential for engine overheating (especially under heavy load or in hot weather).

causes: Faulty third cooling fan motor, faulty third cooling fan relay, wiring issues to the fan or relay, faulty coolant temperature sensor, faulty PCM.

title: Cooling Fan Rationality Check Malfunction
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected an inconsistency in the operation of the cooling fan system compared to the engine temperature.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, cooling fan operation not matching engine temperature, potential for engine overheating.
causes: Faulty cooling fan motor(s), faulty cooling fan relay(s), faulty coolant temperature sensor, PCM problem.

severity: Moderate to High - Can lead to engine overheating.

title: Cooling Fan Circuit Over Current
description: This code indicates that the PCM has detected an excessive amount of current in the cooling fan circuit.

title: Cooling Fan Power/Ground Circuit Malfunction

title: Serial Communication Link Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the serial communication link, often the Controller Area Network (CAN) bus, preventing different electronic control units (ECUs) from communicating properly.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, various other warning lights may illuminate (ABS, transmission, etc.), multiple system malfunctions, engine may not start or run poorly, erratic gauge readings.
causes: Wiring issues in the communication bus (open, short, high resistance), faulty ECU(s), PCM problem.
solutions: Inspect wiring harness and connectors for damage or corrosion, diagnose individual ECUs for faults, diagnose PCM. This often requires specialized diagnostic equipment.
severity: High - Can cause widespread system failures.
diagnosis: Use a specialized scan tool capable of reading communication bus data. Check for communication with different ECUs. Inspect wiring and connectors for the CAN bus.

title: Internal Control Module Memory Check Sum Error
description: This code indicates an internal fault within the Powertrain Control Module (PCM) related to a memory checksum error.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, various drivability problems, engine may not start or run poorly, transmission shifting issues.
causes: Faulty PCM.
solutions: Replace the PCM. This will likely require programming to the specific vehicle.
severity: High - Requires PCM replacement.
diagnosis: This code often indicates an internal PCM failure. Follow manufacturer-specific diagnostic procedures for confirmation.

title: Control Module Programming Error
description: This code indicates an error occurred during the programming of the Powertrain Control Module (PCM) or another control module.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, various drivability problems, engine may not start or run poorly, transmission shifting issues.
causes: Incomplete or incorrect PCM programming.
solutions: Reprogram the PCM with the correct software.
severity: High - Requires PCM reprogramming.
diagnosis: Verify the PCM programming status. Reprogram the PCM using the correct procedure and software.

title: Internal Control Module Keep Alive Memory (KAM) Error
description: This code indicates an internal fault within the Powertrain Control Module (PCM) related to the Keep Alive Memory (KAM).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, loss of learned settings (e.g., idle trim), engine may not run optimally after battery disconnection.
causes: Faulty PCM.
solutions: Replace the PCM.
severity: Moderate - May affect engine performance and learned settings.
diagnosis: This code often indicates an internal PCM failure. Follow manufacturer-specific diagnostic procedures for confirmation.

title: Internal Control Module Random Access Memory (RAM) Error
description: This code indicates an internal fault within the Powertrain Control Module (PCM) related to the Random Access Memory (RAM).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, various drivability problems, engine may not start or run poorly, transmission shifting issues.
causes: Faulty PCM.

title: Transmission Control System Malfunction
description: This code indicates a general malfunction within the Transmission Control System (TCS) or Transmission Control Module (TCM). It often means that the PCM has detected a problem and is indicating that further diagnosis of the TCM is needed.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, transmission shifting problems (erratic, harsh, delayed), transmission may be stuck in one gear (limp mode), reduced fuel economy.
causes: Faulty Transmission Control Module (TCM), wiring issues between the PCM/ECM and TCM, faulty sensors related to the transmission (e.g., speed sensors, temperature sensor), low or contaminated transmission fluid.
solutions: Check transmission fluid level and condition, inspect wiring and connectors related to the transmission and TCM, diagnose and replace faulty transmission sensors, diagnose and replace faulty TCM, diagnose PCM/ECM.
severity: Moderate to High - Can lead to significant transmission damage if not addressed.
diagnosis: Use an advanced OBD-II scanner capable of reading TCM codes. Check for other transmission-related codes. Inspect wiring and fluid. Follow manufacturer-specific diagnostic procedures for the TCM.

title: Transmission Control System Range/Performance
description: This code indicates that the Transmission Control System (TCS) is not performing as expected within a specific range of operation.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, abnormal shifting patterns, transmission slipping, delayed engagement.
causes: Low or contaminated transmission fluid, faulty transmission sensors, faulty solenoids within the transmission, mechanical problems within the transmission, faulty TCM.
solutions: Check and replace transmission fluid, diagnose and replace faulty sensors, diagnose and replace faulty solenoids, address mechanical transmission issues, diagnose and replace faulty TCM.
severity: Moderate - Can lead to transmission damage.
diagnosis: Use an advanced OBD-II scanner to monitor transmission parameters. Check fluid level and condition. Perform transmission tests as per manufacturer guidelines.

title: Transmission Control System Electrical
description: This code indicates a general electrical problem within the Transmission Control System (TCS).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, various transmission issues including no shifting, erratic shifting, or being stuck in gear.
causes: Wiring issues (shorts, opens, corrosion) in the transmission circuits, faulty internal transmission wiring harness, faulty solenoids, faulty sensors, faulty TCM.
solutions: Inspect and repair wiring and connectors, replace faulty internal wiring harness, diagnose and replace faulty solenoids or sensors, diagnose and replace faulty TCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Can cause complete transmission failure.
diagnosis: Use an advanced OBD-II scanner to pinpoint the specific electrical fault within the transmission system. Check wiring diagrams and perform electrical tests.

diagnosis: Check the signal from brake switch B with a scan tool. Inspect the switch and its adjustment. Check wiring.

title: Brake Switch Circuit Malfunction

title: Transmission Range Sensor Circuit Malfunction (PRNDL Input)

symptoms: Check Engine Light, inability to start the engine in Park or Neutral, incorrect gear indication on the dashboard, transmission may start in gear, transmission shifting problems.
causes: Faulty Transmission Range Sensor (TRS), misadjusted TRS, wiring issues to the TRS, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty Transmission Range Sensor (TRS), adjust TRS, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: High - Can affect starting and safe operation of the vehicle.
diagnosis: Check the signal from the TRS with a scan tool for each gear position. Inspect the sensor adjustment and wiring.

title: Transmission Range Sensor Circuit Range/Performance

title: Shift Malfunction
description: This code indicates a general problem with the transmission's ability to shift gears correctly.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, transmission may not shift, may skip gears, or shift erratically.
causes: Low or contaminated transmission fluid, faulty shift solenoids, faulty transmission sensors (speed, temperature), internal mechanical problems within the transmission, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Check and replace transmission fluid, diagnose and replace faulty solenoids or sensors, address internal transmission issues, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Can lead to significant transmission damage.
diagnosis: Use an advanced OBD-II scanner to monitor transmission parameters and identify any specific solenoid or sensor codes. Check fluid level and condition. Perform transmission tests.

title: 1-2 Shift Malfunction

solutions: Check and replace transmission fluid, diagnose and replace faulty shift solenoid(s), address internal transmission issues, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Affects drivability and can lead to further transmission damage.
diagnosis: Monitor shift solenoid operation and gear ratios with a scan tool during the 1-2 shift. Check transmission fluid condition. Perform transmission tests.

severity: Moderate to High - Affects drivability and can lead to further transmission damage.
diagnosis: Monitor shift solenoid operation and gear ratios with a scan tool during the 2-3 shift. Check transmission fluid condition. Perform transmission tests.

severity: Moderate to High - Affects drivability and can lead to further transmission damage.

title: Shift/Timing Solenoid  A High
description: This code indicates a high voltage condition in the control circuit for Shift/Timing Solenoid  A.

severity: Moderate - Affects shifting.
diagnosis: Check voltage at the solenoid connector. Inspect wiring for shorts to power.

title: Shift/Timing Solenoid  A Intermittent
description: This code indicates an intermittent problem with Shift/Timing Solenoid  A.

description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the Intermediate Shaft Speed (ISS) Sensor  A, which measures the speed of an internal shaft within the transmission.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, abnormal shifting, transmission slipping, erratic speedometer readings.

severity: Moderate - Affects transmission operation and potentially speedometer.
diagnosis: Check the voltage and signal from the ISS  A with a scan tool. Inspect wiring and connections.

title: Intermediate Shaft Speed Sensor  A Circuit Range/Performance
description: This code indicates that the signal from the Intermediate Shaft Speed (ISS) Sensor  A is outside the expected range.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, abnormal shifting, transmission slipping, erratic speedometer.
causes: Faulty Intermediate Shaft Speed (ISS) Sensor  A, incorrect sensor installation, damaged reluctor wheel, faulty TCM/PCM.

severity: Moderate - Affects transmission operation and speedometer.
diagnosis: Monitor the ISS  A signal with a scan tool and compare to expected values based on input and output speeds.

title: Intermediate Shaft Speed Sensor  A Circuit No Signal
description: This code indicates that the TCM/PCM is not receiving a signal from the Intermediate Shaft Speed (ISS) Sensor  A.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, transmission may not shift, may be stuck in one gear, speedometer issues.
causes: Faulty Intermediate Shaft Speed (ISS) Sensor  A, broken wiring, faulty TCM/PCM.

severity: High - Affects transmission operation and speedometer.
diagnosis: Check for a signal from the ISS  A with a scan tool while the engine is running and vehicle is moving (if possible).

title: Intermediate Shaft Speed Sensor  A Circuit Intermittent
description: This code indicates an intermittent or erratic signal from the Intermediate Shaft Speed (ISS) Sensor  A circuit.
symptoms: Intermittent Check Engine Light, occasional abnormal shifting, temporary speedometer issues.

solutions: Check and secure wiring, replace faulty ISS  A sensor, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects transmission operation and speedometer.

severity: Moderate to High - Affects transmission operation.

severity: High - Can lead to transmission damage.
diagnosis: Monitor solenoid C commanded and actual pressure with a scan tool. Check for harsh shifting.

title: Pressure Control Solenoid C Electrical
description: This code indicates a general electrical fault within Pressure Control Solenoid C circuit.

solutions: Inspect and repair wiring, replace faulty Pressure Control Solenoid C, diagnose faulty TCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Affects transmission operation.
diagnosis: Check voltage and control signals to solenoid C. Inspect wiring.

description: This code indicates an intermittent electrical or mechanical problem with Pressure Control Solenoid C.
symptoms: Intermittent Check Engine Light, occasional abnormal shifting or slipping.
causes: Loose/corroded wiring to solenoid C, intermittent fault in solenoid C, faulty TCM.
solutions: Check and secure wiring, replace faulty Pressure Control Solenoid C, diagnose faulty TCM.

diagnosis: Monitor control signals to solenoid C for dropouts. Check wiring and connections.

title: Transmission Control System (TCS) Malfunction Indicator Lamp (MIL) Request
description: This code indicates that the Transmission Control Module (TCM) has requested the Malfunction Indicator Lamp (MIL) to illuminate due to a transmission-related fault.
symptoms: Check Engine Light.
causes: A fault has been detected within the Transmission Control System (TCS) that warrants illuminating the MIL. Refer to other P07xx codes for the specific issue.
solutions: Diagnose and repair the underlying transmission-related fault indicated by other P07xx codes.
severity: Moderate to High - Indicates a transmission problem.
diagnosis: Use an advanced OBD-II scanner to retrieve any P07xx codes stored by the TCM. Diagnose and repair those codes.

title: Reverse Inhibit Control Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit that controls the reverse inhibit function, which may prevent shifting into reverse under certain conditions.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, inability to shift into reverse, reverse gear may engage unexpectedly.
causes: Faulty reverse inhibit solenoid or actuator, wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty reverse inhibit solenoid or actuator, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects the ability to use reverse gear safely.
diagnosis: Check voltage and control signals to the reverse inhibit component. Inspect wiring and connections.

title: Transmission Control System (TCS) Malfunction Indicator Lamp (MIL) Request Circuit Open
description: This code indicates an open circuit in the electrical circuit between the TCM and the MIL request line to the PCM/ECM.
symptoms: Check Engine Light not illuminating for transmission faults.
causes: Open circuit in wiring between TCM and PCM/ECM, faulty TCM, faulty PCM/ECM.
solutions: Repair open circuit, diagnose faulty TCM, diagnose faulty PCM/ECM.
severity: Low to Moderate - Affects the ability to see transmission warning lights.
diagnosis: Check continuity of the wiring between the TCM and the PCM/ECM MIL request line.

title: Upshift Solenoid Control Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit that controls the upshift solenoid(s) in the transmission.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, transmission not upshifting correctly.
causes: Faulty upshift solenoid(s), wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty upshift solenoid(s), repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects transmission shifting.
diagnosis: Check voltage and control signals to the upshift solenoid(s). Inspect wiring.

title: Upshift Lamp Control Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the upshift indicator lamp (if equipped).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, upshift indicator lamp not working correctly.
causes: Faulty upshift indicator lamp, wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty upshift indicator lamp, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Low - Primarily affects indicator function.
diagnosis: Check voltage to the upshift indicator lamp. Inspect wiring.

title: Clutch Position Sensor Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the clutch position sensor (for manual or automated manual transmissions).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, difficulty shifting, clutch may not engage or disengage properly.
causes: Faulty clutch position sensor, wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty clutch position sensor, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects shifting.
diagnosis: Check voltage and signal from the clutch position sensor. Inspect wiring.

title: Clutch Position Sensor Circuit Range/Performance
description: This code indicates that the signal from the clutch position sensor is outside the expected range.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, difficulty shifting, clutch may not engage or disengage at the correct point.
causes: Faulty clutch position sensor, misadjusted sensor, wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty clutch position sensor, adjust sensor, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects shifting.
diagnosis: Monitor clutch position sensor readings with a scan tool. Check sensor adjustment.

title: Clutch Position Sensor Circuit Low
description: This code indicates a low voltage condition in the clutch position sensor circuit.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, difficulty shifting, clutch may not disengage.
causes: Faulty clutch position sensor, short to ground, wiring issue, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty clutch position sensor, repair short, check wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects shifting.
diagnosis: Check voltage at the clutch position sensor connector. Inspect wiring for shorts to ground.

title: Clutch Position Sensor Circuit High
description: This code indicates a high voltage condition in the clutch position sensor circuit.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, difficulty shifting, clutch may not engage.
causes: Faulty clutch position sensor, short to power, wiring issue, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty clutch position sensor, repair short, check wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects shifting.
diagnosis: Check voltage at the clutch position sensor connector. Inspect wiring for shorts to power.

title: Clutch Position Sensor Circuit Intermittent
description: This code indicates an intermittent problem with the signal from the clutch position sensor circuit.
symptoms: Intermittent Check Engine Light, occasional difficulty shifting.
causes: Loose/corroded wiring to sensor, intermittent sensor failure, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Check and secure wiring, replace faulty clutch position sensor, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects shifting.
diagnosis: Monitor clutch position sensor signal for dropouts. Check wiring.

title: Clutch Position Control Error
description: This code indicates that the Transmission Control Module (TCM) has detected an error in the control of the clutch position (for automated manual transmissions).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, difficulty shifting, clutch slipping, clutch may not engage or disengage properly.
causes: Faulty clutch actuator, faulty clutch position sensor, wiring issues, low clutch fluid (if hydraulic), faulty TCM.
solutions: Diagnose and replace faulty clutch actuator or position sensor, repair wiring, check clutch fluid, diagnose faulty TCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Affects shifting and clutch operation.
diagnosis: Monitor clutch position and actuator operation with a scan tool. Check clutch fluid level and condition.

title: Excessive Clutch Slippage
description: This code indicates that the Transmission Control Module (TCM) has detected excessive slippage of the clutch (for manual or automated manual transmissions).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, clutch slipping during acceleration, difficulty shifting, loss of power.
causes: Worn clutch, faulty clutch actuator, incorrect clutch adjustment, low clutch fluid (if hydraulic), faulty TCM.
solutions: Replace worn clutch, diagnose and replace faulty clutch actuator, adjust clutch, check and replenish clutch fluid, diagnose faulty TCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Affects drivability and can lead to clutch damage.
diagnosis: Monitor clutch slippage with a scan tool (if available). Check clutch pedal travel and adjustment. Inspect clutch components.

title: Reverse Input Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the reverse gear input to the TCM/PCM (often from the Transmission Range Sensor or a dedicated reverse switch).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, reverse lights may not work, inability to select reverse gear, transmission may engage reverse unexpectedly.
causes: Faulty Transmission Range Sensor (TRS) or reverse switch, wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty TRS or reverse switch, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects the ability to use reverse gear safely.
diagnosis: Check the voltage and signal from the reverse input circuit. Inspect wiring and the TRS/reverse switch.

title: Reverse Output Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit that controls the reverse lights or other reverse gear outputs from the TCM/PCM.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, reverse lights not working when in reverse.
causes: Faulty TCM/PCM, wiring issues to the reverse lights or other outputs, faulty reverse light relay.
solutions: Diagnose faulty TCM/PCM, repair wiring, replace faulty reverse light relay.
severity: Low - Primarily affects reverse light function.
diagnosis: Check for voltage at the reverse lights when the vehicle is in reverse. Inspect wiring and the relay.

title: Transmission Range Display Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit that controls the transmission range display (PRNDL) on the instrument cluster.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, incorrect gear indication on the dashboard.
causes: Faulty instrument cluster, wiring issues between TCM/PCM and instrument cluster, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Diagnose faulty instrument cluster, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Low - Primarily affects the accuracy of the gear display.
diagnosis: Check the signals from the TCM/PCM to the instrument cluster for the gear selection. Inspect wiring.

title: Upshift Switch Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the manual upshift switch (for transmissions with manual control).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, inability to manually upshift.
causes: Faulty upshift switch, wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty upshift switch, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Low - Affects manual shifting function.
diagnosis: Check the signal from the upshift switch with a scan tool. Inspect wiring.

title: Downshift Switch Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the manual downshift switch (for transmissions with manual control).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, inability to manually downshift.
causes: Faulty downshift switch, wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty downshift switch, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Low - Affects manual shifting function.
diagnosis: Check the signal from the downshift switch with a scan tool. Inspect wiring.

title: Starter Disable Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit that disables the starter under certain conditions (e.g., when not in Park or Neutral for automatics, or clutch not depressed for manuals).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, engine may crank in gear, inability to start in Park or Neutral (automatics).
causes: Faulty Transmission Range Sensor (automatics), faulty clutch position sensor (manuals), wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Diagnose and replace faulty sensor, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects safety and starting.
diagnosis: Check the signals from the relevant sensors with a scan tool in different conditions. Inspect wiring.

title: Driveline Disconnect Switch Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the driveline disconnect switch (if equipped, often in 4WD systems).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, inability to engage or disengage 4WD, 4WD indicator light issues.
causes: Faulty driveline disconnect switch, wiring issues, faulty transfer case control module (TCCM), faulty PCM/TCM.
solutions: Replace faulty switch, repair wiring, diagnose TCCM, diagnose PCM/TCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects 4WD system operation.
diagnosis: Check the signal from the driveline disconnect switch. Inspect wiring and the TCCM.

title: Upshift/Downshift Switch to Transmission Range Correlation
description: This code indicates a problem with the correlation between the manual upshift/downshift switch inputs and the actual transmission range (gear).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, incorrect gear selection when using manual controls.
causes: Faulty upshift/downshift switches, faulty Transmission Range Sensor, wiring issues, faulty TCM/PCM.
solutions: Replace faulty upshift/downshift switches, replace faulty TRS, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM/PCM.
severity: Moderate - Affects manual shifting accuracy.
diagnosis: Monitor the signals from the upshift/downshift switches and the TRS with a scan tool while manually shifting.

title: Gear Lever X-Y Position Sensor Circuit Malfunction
description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the gear lever X-Y position sensor (used in some manual or automated manual transmissions with joystick-style shifters).
symptoms: Check Engine Light, difficulty selecting gears, incorrect gear selection displayed.

description: This code indicates a problem with the electrical circuit for the Transmission Fluid Pressure (TFP) sensor E.
symptoms: Check Engine Light, abnormal shifting, transmission slipping.
causes: Faulty TFP sensor E, wiring issues, faulty TCM.
solutions: Replace faulty TFP sensor E, repair wiring, diagnose faulty TCM.
severity: Moderate to High - Affects transmission operation.
diagnosis: Check voltage and signal from TFP sensor E. Inspect wiring.
